sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: gdialog is a command prompt application which displays GNOME dialog boxes. It is used display dialog boxes within shell scripts.
gdialog is included in the gnome-utils package, which is part of the GNOME desktop environment. This document describes version &version; of gdialog.

sect2.title: Basic usage
sect2.para:
gdialog is used in shell scripts or from the command prompt. To use gdialog, give instructions describing the dialog to be created on the command line or in a shell script. For example,
gdialog --msgbox "Here's a test message !" 200 150
creates and displays the dialog box shown in .
gdialog example
gdialog msgbox example
The complete command line options list for gdialog is:
title specifies the title for the dialog.

"Box Options" can be one of the following:
[--defaultno] --yesno text height width
--msgbox text height width
--infobox text height width
--inputbox text height width [init]
--textbox file height width
--menu text height width menu height tag1 item1 ...
--checklist text height width list height tag1 item1 status1 ...
--radiolist text height width list height tag1 item1 status1 ...
--gauge text height width percent
--guage file text height width percent

sect1.title: Using different types of dialog boxes

sect2.title: Creating a Confirmation Dialog
sect2.para:
To create a dialog box showing a question and a "Yes" and a "No" button, use the --yesno option. To create a dialog box with the title as "My Dialog", and question to be shown "Should I exit ?" use the following command:
gdialog --title "My Dialog" --yesno "Should I exit ?" 250 150

The above command displays the dialog box shown in figure .
Confirmation Box Example
gdialog confirmation box example
The return value from gdialog is 0 if the user clicked on "Yes" and 1 if the user clicked on "No".
By default, the "Yes" button is highlighted when the dialog is displayed. In case you want the "No" button to be highlighted, add --defaultno

sect2.title: Creating a Message Box
sect2.para:
You can create a dialog box that shows a message using the --msgbox option. To create a dialog box with the title as "My Dialog", and message to be shown "Here's a message !" use the following command:
gdialog --title "My Dialog" --msgbox "Here's a message" 250 150

The above command displays the dialog box shown in figure .
Message box example
gdialog message box example
